information: The marks for questions are shown in brackets.
The m aximum mark for this paper is 90.
advice: You are advised to spend 70 minutes on Section A and 50 minutes on Section B . Please write clearly in block capitals.
Place a conical flask on a balance and add approximately 20 g of
Add 50 cm3 of 0.4 mol dm–3 hydrochloric acid.
Place a loose cotton wool plug in the neck of the flask.
Zero the mass reading on the balance.
Record the loss in mass ( mt) every 30 seconds for 4 minutes.
Wait for the reaction to finish and record the total mass loss ( mtotal).
Plot a graph of ( mtotal – mt) against time.

questions.t: 1 The structure of 2 -hydroxybenzenecarboxylic acid is shown. 0 1 . 1 Give the equation for the reaction of 2 -hydroxybenzenecarboxylic acid with methanol. In your equation, include the skeletal formula of the organic product. [2 mark s] Aspirin is produced from 2 -hydroxybenzenecarboxylic acid by reaction with ethanoic anhydride in the presence of concentrated phosphoric acid. Method 1. Add 2-hydroxybenzenecarboxylic acid to a conical flask. 2. Add excess ethanoic anhydride. 3. Add a few drops of concentrated phosphoric acid. 4. Heat the flask to 85 °C for 10 minutes. 5. Cool the flask and pour the contents into 150 cm3 of cold water. 6. Filter and wash the impure solid aspirin. 7. Recrystallise the aspirin using a 50:50 mixture of water and ethanol. 8. Check the purity of the aspirin. 0 1 . 2 Aspirin can also be produced by reacting 2 -hydroxybenzenecarboxylic acid with ethanoyl chloride. State why ethanoic anhydride is preferred to ethanoyl chloride for this preparation. 3 *03* Turn over IB/M/Jun24/7405/3 Do not write outside the box 0 1 . 3 Give the name of the mechanism for the reaction of 2-hydroxybenzenecarboxylic acid with ethanoic anhydride. 0 1 . 4 Suggest the role of the concentrated phosphoric acid. 0 1 . 5 Suggest why reflux is not essential when the flask is heated to 85 °C for 10 minutes. 0 1 . 6 Complete and label the diagram to show how the impure solid is filtered. [2 mark s] 4 *04* IB/M/Jun24/7405/3 Do not write outside the box 0 1 . 7 Suggest the identity of two impurities present in the filtered solid aspirin before it is washed in Step 6 of the method. [2 mark s] Impurity 1 Impurity 2 0 1 . 8 Describe the recrystallisation process used to purify the aspirin. Include the method and apparatus used. [6 mark s] 5 *05* Turn over IB/M/Jun24/7405/3 Do not write outside the box 0 1 . 9 State the physical property that is measured to check the purity of the aspirin. Describe two ways the result would show that the product is impure. Physical property 1 2 19 6 *06* IB/M/Jun24/7405/3 Do not write outside the box 0 2 The rate of reaction between calcium carbonate and hydrochloric acid is investigated using a continuous monitoring method. Method • Place a conical flask on a balance and add approximately 20 g of large marble chips. • Add 50 cm3 of 0.4 mol dm–3 hydrochloric acid. • Place a loose cotton wool plug in the neck of the flask. • Zero the mass reading on the balance. • Start a timer. • Record the loss in mass ( mt) every 30 seconds for 4 minutes. • Wait for the reaction to finish and record the total mass loss ( mtotal). • Plot a graph of ( mtotal – mt) against time. Figure 1 shows a graph of the results obtained during the first 240 s Figure 1 0 2 . 1 Suggest why a loose cotton wool plug is placed in the neck of the flask, instead of leaving the flask open or inserting a bung. Instead of leaving the flask open Instead of inserting a bung 7 *07* Turn over IB/M/Jun24/7405/3 Do not write outside the box 0 2 . 2 20 g of large marble chips is a large excess of calcium carbonate. Suggest why using a large excess of calcium carbonate means that the rate is only affected by the changing concentration of the hydrochloric acid. 0 2 . 3 The mass of carbon dioxide produced in time t is equal to m t. The total mass of CO 2 produced during the reaction is equal to mtotal. Explain why ( mtotal – mt) is proportional to the concentration of hydrochloric acid remaining in the flask at time t. [2 mark s] 8 *08* IB/M/Jun24/7405/3 Do not write outside the box 0 2 . 4 Table 1 shows the rate of reaction, calculated from the gradient of the curve, at five different times. (mtotal – mt) is proportional to the concentration of unreacted HC l at time t. Table 1 Rate of reaction / g s–1 23.0 × 10–4 19.0 × 10–4 15.7 × 10–4 11.5 × 10–4 6.67 × 10–4 (mtotal – mt) / g 0.340 0.280 0.225 0.170 0.100 On the grid in Figure 2 plot the rate of reaction (y-axis) against ( mtotal – mt) (x-axis). Figure 2 9 *09* Turn over IB/M/Jun24/7405/3 Do not write outside the box 0 2 . 5 State how the graph in Figure 2 confirms that the rate equation for this reaction is Rate = k[HCl] 0 2 . 6 In this experiment the variable measured is mass loss. The rate of this reaction at a constant temperature can be investigated in other ways. Suggest two other variables that can be measured instead of mass loss. 1 2 11 10 *10* IB/M/Jun24/7405/3 Do not write outside the box 0 3 The thermal decomposition of but -3-en-1-ol is investigated at different temperatures ( T ). o.t: The dissociation of water into ions is an exothermic process.
The pH of water is the same at 25 °C and at 18 °C
Water becomes less acidic as the temperature is raised.
Sodium has the smallest atomic radius.
Aluminium has the highest melting point.
Chlorine has the highest first ionisation energy.

The bond dissociation energy of H –X increases.

The solubility of AgX in ammonia increases.
They are oxidised by concentrated sulfuric acid.

They form a cobalt(II) complex with a tetrahedral shape.
Butanedioic acid is one of the reactants used to make nylon- 6,6

All molecules of nylon- 6,6 have the same relative molecular mass.

The reaction is slower than fermentation.

An increase in pressure, at constant temperature, increases the equilibrium yield of ethanol.
